book.title: JATS Tagging Guidelines for NPG/Palgrave articles

preface.title: Introduction
preface.para: These Tagging Guidelines describe NPG's preferred XML tagging style for journal article submissions in NISO JATS Journal Publishing DTD. All deliveries made to NPG must conform to the provisions of this document.

The Tagging Guidelines are divided into separate chapters. Each chapter describes separate rules that must be followed when creating NPG-style compliant XML. Many of the rules are related, but none are duplicated from one chapter to another.

listitem.para: General tagging practice: These style rules apply to structured data tagging at a very broad level and include emphasised text, mathematics, and special characters.
Document objects: This chapter describes specific parts of XML documents like figures, tables and author/affiliation relationships. It includes examples of XML tagging.

Elements: This chapter describes style rules for specific XML elements and their attributes. Only elements for which NPG has a style rule are described in this section. Refer to the JATS Tag Library for descriptions of all elements available in the DTD.

simplesect.title: A note on presentation
simplesect.para: Elements are shown within angled brackets. Attributes are preceeded by the @ sign. Both are shown in a monospace font to distinguish them from regular text.

simplesect.title: Packaging format
simplesect.para: XML files should be uploaded to the NPG XML Gateway for validation against DTD and Schematron rules. Associated binary files (images, pdfs etc) should continue to be submitted to the ftp site. This is likely to change in the future with all files submitted together to the XML Gateway.

chapter.title: General tagging practice
chapter.para: The XML should conform to the JATS Journal Publishing DTD, version 1.0 incorporating the Oasis table model. The DTD is available from the stable ftp site: ftp://ftp.ncbi.nih.gov/pub/jats/publishing/1.0/
The main module of the DTD we use is JATS-journalpublishing-oasis-article1.dtd. It imports the subordinate modules. For the schema to work, all modules must be in the same directory.
The complete JATS Tag Library is available on the web: http://jats.nlm.nih.gov/publishing/tag-library/1.0/index.html

section.title: DOCTYPE declaration
section.para: Set the PUBLIC identifier to "-//NLM//DTD JATS (Z39.96) Journal Publishing DTD with OASIS Tables v1.0 20120330//EN".
section.programlisting: <!DOCTYPE article PUBLIC "-//NLM//DTD JATS (Z39.96) Journal Publishing DTD with OASIS Tables v1.0 20120330//EN" "JATS-journalpublishing-oasis-article1.dtd">

section.title: Emphasised text
section.para: As a rule, use emphasised text markup (, , , etc) only to set off a piece of information. Do not set entire elements in emphasised text. For example, if a is set completely in boldface, do not use the <bold>. However, if a title has a word or some words set in boldface for emphasis, tag those words using <bold>. Mainly this will apply to <title>, <p> in <abstract>, <label> and entries in <oasis:thead>. It might also show up in <aff> and "special" sections, like <ack>.

section.title: Empty elements
section.para: Do not use empty elements for the purpose of formatting, except where stated below. All required elements should have content.

section.title: Links
section.para: Tag all internal links within the document (e.g. tables, figures, display formulae) with the <xref> element and include the appropriate @ref-type. See <xref>.

Tag all links to related articles (e.g. from a correction to the corrected article) with <related-article> and include the appropriate @ext-link-type, @related-article-type, and citation information. See <related-article>.
Tag all external links with <ext-link> and include the appropriate @ext-link-type. See <ext-link>.

section.title: Mathematics
section.para: Tag all display formulae with MathML markup and capture an image. MathML 2.0 is included in the JATS DTD.

Tag an inline formula with MathML markup when it cannot be represented by regular article elements and Unicode characters. [Add definition for what counts as a formula - equals sign and equivalents, not just +, −, / or ×] For example, [*give examples - nutd201220 inline-formulae*]
Use <mml:math> to tag mathematical expressions only. Do not use it to tag single characters.

section.title: Use of Unicode
section.para: Do not use named character entities within JATS markup, apart from the predefined XML entities (< for <, > for >, and & for &).
Tag non-ASCII characters with their Unicode hex number in character entity style (e.g. × for × and g̃ for g̃).

Do not use values from the Private Use Areas: xE000–xF8FF, xF0000–xFFFFD, and x100000–x10FFFD. Do not use Unicode values designated as control codes. These ranges include but are not limited to x0000–0020, x0080–x009F.
[*Info from Jude on "unsafe" entities which will require Stix fonts*]

section.title: Mimetypes and mime subtypes
section.para: For <graphic> and <supplementary-material> use the following values for @mimetype and @mime-subtype:

chapter.title: Document structures
chapter.para: These Document Objects refer to pieces of the XML documents that define a single concept (author/affiliation relationships, copyright information etc) and often include several XML elements in their tagging.

sect1.title: Article
sect1.para: See <article> for information on tagging the root <article> element.
All articles will contain <front> and most will contain <body>, <back> and <floats-group>. More detailed information on these sections is given below.
<sub-article> may be used occasionally for correspondence and reviews.
Do not use <response>.

sect1.title: Front
sect1.para: <front> should contain <journal-meta> and <article-meta>. Do not use <notes> in <front>.

sect2.title: Journal metadata
sect2.para:
<journal-meta> contains minimal journal metadata:
pcode/journal id
journal title
ISSN(s), and
publisher name
sect2.programlisting: <journal-meta> <journal-id journal-id-type="publisher">sth</journal-id> <journal-title-group> <journal-title>Social Theory and Health</journal-title> </journal-title-group> <issn pub-type="ppub">1477-8211</issn> <issn pub-type="epub">1477-822X</issn> <publisher> <publisher-name>Palgrave Macmillan</publisher-name> </publisher> </journal-meta>

sect2.title: References
sect2.para: A reference list (<ref-list>) is a series of references (<ref>). Generally each reference item contains only one citation element. For NPG articles, use <mixed-citation> for all references.

sect1.title: Floating objects
sect1.para: All figures, illustrations, tables, boxes and supplementary material should be captured in <floats-group>.

sect2.title: Figures
sect2.para: Figures are the block-level objects that usually contain an image and are captured using <fig>.
Characteristics of a figure which should be captured within <floats-group>:

listitem.para: It has a label like "Figure 1" or "Graph 2".
It has a title or caption.
It is referenced by an <xref> with @ref-type="fig" in the article text.

sect3.para: <fig> should only contain the following optional child elements: <label>, <caption>, <alternatives>, <graphic>, and <attrib>.
The @id attribute should follow the format of "f" + the label number, e.g. id="f1". Do not use any other attributes on <fig>.

sect3.title: Label
sect3.para: <label> should only be used if the figure label is not of the standard "Figure" + number format, e.g. "Map 1". See Figure sample 1.
Do not use any attributes on <label>.

sect3.title: Caption
sect3.para: may contain and/or <p> child elements. <p> is used to capture introductory text or key information for the figure).
Do not use any attributes on <caption> or its child elements.

sect3.title: Images and slides
sect3.para: Capture the figure image(s) as <graphic> elements. If the figure has more than one image, they do not need to be wrapped in the <alternatives> tag, unless slide alternatives are also provided See Figure samples 1 and 2.
Only the main image should be referenced in the XML; do not include <graphic> elements for thumbails or other alternative image sizes.

Where a slide alternative is provided for an image, capture it as <supplementary-material> with attribute value @content-type="slide". The <graphic> and <supplementary-material> elements must then be wrapped in an <alternatives> tag. See Figure samples 3 and 4.

Other required attributes for both images and slides in figures:
position—must be ="anchor" for all images/slides in tables
xlink:href—image/slide filename, including the extension
mimetype—based on the filename extension. See Mimetypes and mime subtypes for the correct mappings.
mime-subtype—based on the filename extension. See Mimetypes and mime subtypes for the correct mappings.
Do not use any other attributes on <graphic> or <supplementary-material> within a figure.
See Figure samples 2, 3 and 4.

sect3.title: Attribution
sect3.para: Do not use any attributes on <attrib> within a figure.
See Figure sample 1.

sect4.title: Figure 1. Basic figure with non-standard label and attribution
sect4.programlisting: <fig id="f1"> <label>Map 1</label> <caption> <title>The Rural/Urban Definition for MSOAs in England</title> </caption> <graphic position="anchor" xlink:href="rt20112f1.gif" mimetype="image" mime-subtype="gif"/> <attrib>Credit: UK Statistics Authority</attrib> </fig>

sect4.title: Figure 2. Figure with multiple images
sect4.programlisting: Schematic illustration for pharmacodynamic modeling (A, B) and pharmacokinetic–pharmacodynamic modeling (C, D). (A) Changes in plasma drug concentration and drug effect over time. (B) The difference in the concentration–effect relationship between the two time points (t1 and t2) when this relationship is modeled using pharmacodynamic model alone. (C) The estimation of effect compartment concentration in pharmacokinetic–pharmacodynamic modeling. (D) The concentration–effect relationship independent of the time point when the data are obtained.

sect4.title: Figure 3. Figure with slide alternative
sect4.programlisting:
Identification of Sema3A as an inhibitory factor of osteoclastdifferentiation.

a, Effect of wild-type (WT) and Opg-deficient (Tnfrsf11b−/−) calvarial cell-conditioned medium on osteoclast differentiation. MNC, mononuclear cells. b, Fractionation of Opg-deficient calvarial cell-conditioned medium by anion-exchange chromatography, and the effect of each fraction on osteoclast differentiation (black bars). c, Coomassie brilliant blue-stained SDS–PAGE image of fraction 8. M, molecular mass. d, List of the identified proteins (that is, more than 300 on the MASCOT score), their theoretical molecular mass, MASCOT score and the number of non-redundant peptides. e, Effect of Sema3A treatment on osteoclast differentiation. Error bars (a, b and e) denote mean ± s.e.m. **P < 0.01; ***P < 0.005; NS, not significant.

sect4.title: Figure 4. Figure with multiple images and slides
sect4.programlisting: Heat map and hierarchical clustering of the relative protein abundances. Heat map presents the log2(abundance ratio). The plots present the time courses of the relative abundances of the proteins in the three treatment stages relative to the baseline. (a) Patient A: Thirty-eight proteins form a group with synchronously changing abundances (see thumbnail 5). (b) Patient B: Sixty-five proteins form a group with synchronously changing abundances (see thumbnail 1). (c) Patient C: Forty-one proteins form a group with synchronously changing abundances (see thumbnail 4). In addition, there is a second group of 58 proteins with abundances growing dramatically in the ‘off’ stage (see thumbnail 6). Red—upregulated, green—downregulated.

sect3.title: Illustrations
sect3.para: More information to be added here.

sect3.title: Infographics
sect3.para: More information to be added here.

sect2.title: Tables
sect2.para: Tables are block-level objects that contain tabular material and are captured using <table-wrap>.
Characteristics of a table which should be captured within <floats-group>:

listitem.para: It has a label like "Table 1" or "Table D2.1".
It has a title or caption.
It is referenced by an <xref> with @ref-type="table" in the article text.

sect2.para: Do not use <table-wrap-group> in NPG articles.

sect3.title: Table wrapper
sect3.para: <table-wrap> should only contain the following optional child elements: <label>, <caption>, <oasis:table>, <alternatives>, <graphic>, <table-wrap-foot>, and <attrib>.
The @id attribute should follow the format of "t" + the label number, e.g. id="t1" or id="tD2.1". Do not use any other attributes on <table-wrap>.

sect3.title: Label
sect3.para: <label> should only be used if the table label is not of the standard "Table" + number format, e.g. "Exhibit 1". See Table sample 1.
Do not use any attributes on <label>.

sect3.title: Caption
sect3.para: <caption> must contain <title>.

An optional

element may also be used to capture any additional introductory text for the table.
Do not use any attributes on <caption> or its child elements.

sect3.title: Table body
sect3.para: The JATS DTD normally uses the HTML table model. As NPG uses the OASIS CALS model, the "oasis" namespace is required on the table element and all of its descendants.
A detailed tag library for the OASIS Open Exchange CALS Table Model can be found at: http://dtd.nlm.nih.gov/options/OASIS/tag-library/19990315/index.html

A table body may be captured as XML (<oasis:table>), an image (<graphic>) and there may also be a slide alternative for the image (<supplementary-material>). Where two or more of these representations are used, they should be wrapped in an <alternatives> tag. See Table samples 4, 5 and 6.

sect4.para: The @frame attribute value should be given. Do not use any other attributes on <oasis:table>.
The @cols attribute value is required by the DTD. Do not use any other attributes on <oasis:tgroup>.
Values for the following attributes must be declared: @colnum, @colname, @align.
Values may be declared for the following attributes: @char (only if @align="char"), @colsep, @rowsep.
Do not use @colwidth or @charoff.
The @valign attribute is only required if it is "top" or "middle". The default value ("bottom") does not need to be stated.
The @valign attribute is only required if it is "bottom" or "middle". The default value ("top") does not need to be stated.
An empty <oasis:entry/> element should be used to show an empty cell.
@break may be used to aid formatting of the output.
@namest and @nameend should be used to show where entries span a number of columns. @align should also be used if it is different to the value declared in the corresponding <oasis:colspec>
Values may also be declared for the following attributes where they are different to the values in the corresponding <oasis:colspec>: @align, @char, @colsep, @rowsep.
Do not use @colwidth or @charoff.

sect3.title: Images and slides
sect3.para: Where an image file is provided for the table, capture this as <graphic>. If the image is to be used for display purposes, rather than <oasis:table>, the attribute value @specific-use="show" must be used.
Where a slide alternative is also provided for the table image, capture this as <supplementary-material> with attribute value @content-type="slide".

Other required attributes for both images and slides in tables:
position—must be ="anchor" for all images/slides in tables
xlink:href—image/slide filename, including the extension
mimetype—based on the filename extension. See Mimetypes and mime subtypes for the correct mappings.
mime-subtype—based on the filename extension. See Mimetypes and mime subtypes for the correct mappings.
Do not use any other attributes on <graphic> or <supplementary-material> within a table.
See Table samples 3, 4, 5 and 6.

sect3.title: Table footer
sect3.para:
should only contain and/or

child elements.

sect4.title: Table footnotes
sect4.para: Table footnotes should be captured in <table-wrap-foot>, not as the final row(s) of <oasis:tbody>.
Do not wrap footnotes in the <fn-group> tag.
The footnote should contain a <label> containing the reference symbol, letter or number.

The @id attribute should follow the format of "t#-fn#" where "t#" is the table @id and "fn#" represents the order of the footnote in the table, e.g. id="t1-fn2" or id="tD2.1-fn6". Do not use any other attributes on <fn> within <table-wrap-foot>.
See Table samples 5 and 6.

sect4.title: Other footer text
sect4.para:
may also contain paragraphs of information about the table that appear after the last row. These should be captured as

.

Do not use any attributes on

within .
See Table samples 2 and 5.

sect3.title: Table attribution
sect3.para: Table attribution information should be captured in <attrib> as a child of <table-wrap> and not within <table-wrap-foot>.
Do not use any attributes on <attrib> within a table.
See Table sample 1.

sect4.title: Table 1. Basic table with non-standard label and attribution
sect4.programlisting: <table-wrap id="t1"> <label>Appendix Table 1</label> <caption> <title>Primer sets used for quantitative real-time PCR analyses</title> </caption> <oasis:table frame="topbot"> <oasis:tgroup cols="3"> <oasis:colspec colnum="1" colname="col1" align="left"/> <oasis:colspec colnum="2" colname="col2" align="left"/> <oasis:colspec colnum="3" colname="col3" align="left"/> <oasis:thead> <oasis:row> <oasis:entry>Gene</oasis:entry> <oasis:entry>Forward primer</oasis:entry> <oasis:entry>Reverse primer</oasis:entry> </oasis:row> </oasis:thead> <oasis:tbody> <oasis:row> <oasis:entry>HSP70</oasis:entry> <oasis:entry>5′-<named-content content-type="gene-seq">AGGCCAGGGCTGGTATTACT </named-content>-3′</oasis:entry> <oasis:entry>5′-<named-content content-type="gene-seq">AATGACCCGAGTTCAGGATG </named-content>-3′</oasis:entry> </oasis:row> <oasis:row> <oasis:entry>HSP32</oasis:entry> <oasis:entry>5′-<named-content content-type="gene-seq">CTCACAGATGGCGTCACTTCGTCA </named-content>-3′</oasis:entry> <oasis:entry>5′-<named-content content-type="gene-seq">TTGCCAACAGGAAGCTGAGA </named-content>-3′</oasis:entry> </oasis:row> </oasis:tbody> </oasis:tgroup> </oasis:table> <attrib>Taken from <ext-link ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="http://www.asia-basket.com/team.asp ?Cntry=South%20Korea&Team=3442&Page=3">Asia-Basket</ext-link></attrib> </table-wrap>

sect4.title: Table 2. Two table groups, spanning entries and table footer text
sect4.programlisting:
Baseline characteristics of obese and non-obese participants (A) Obese; BMI ⩾25 (N=262) Non-obese; BMI <25 (N=136) Mean±s.d. Min–Max Mean±s.d. Min–Max Age (years) 35±10.45 18–72 31±8.51 18–72 BW (kg) 93.0±22.77 57.6–188.5 55.8±8.05 41.0–77.9 ... (B) Obese; BMI ⩾25 (N=262) Non-obese; BMI <25 (N=136) Number of patients (%) Mean±s.d. Gender (M/F) 112 (42.7%)/150 (57.3%) 50 (36.8%)/ 86 (63.2%) ...

Abbreviations: BMI, body mass index; BW, bodyweight; DBP, diastolic blood pressure; F, female; FPG, fasting plasma glucose; HC, hip circumference; HOMA-IR, homeostasis model assessment for insulin resistance; IGT, impaired glucose tolerance; M, male; MetS, metabolic syndrome; PC-2 h, plasma glucose 2 h post oral challenge; SBP, systolic blood pressure; TC, total plasma cholesterol; TG, plasma triglycerides; WC, waist circumference; WHR, waist-hip ratio.

The mean±s.d. is shown for continuous parameters, and the number of patients (%) is shown for those with metabolic conditions.

sect4.title: Table 3. Image only
sect4.programlisting: <table-wrap id="t3"> <caption> <title>Clinical and laboratory parameters over time for the three patients treated with bortezomib-based regimen (patient 2)</title> </caption> <graphic position="anchor" xlink:href="gim2012110t3.gif" mimetype="image" mime-subtype="gif" specific-use="show"/> </table-wrap>

sect4.title: Table 4. Image and slide
sect4.programlisting: <table-wrap id="t4"> <caption> <title>Clinical and laboratory parameters over time for the three patients treated with bortezomib-based regimen (patient 3)</title> </caption> <alternatives> <graphic position="anchor" xlink:href="gim2012110t4.gif" mimetype="image" mime-subtype="gif" specific-use="show"/> <supplementary-material content-type="slide" position="anchor" xlink:href="gim2012110-pt4.ppt" mimetype="application" mime-subtype="vnd.ms-powerpoint"></supplementary-material> </alternatives> </table-wrap>

sect4.title: Table 5. XML and image - image used for display purposes; mix of table footnotes and footer text
sect4.programlisting:
Results of homogeneity tests of statistical artifacts Statistical artifacts nested in TCE determinants Mean effect size Standard error P-value Q-value Advertising intensity (AI) OBE measure  Binary 0.07 0.02 24.21a ...

P<0.01.

Abbreviations: OBE: Operation break-even.

sect4.title: Table 6. XML and image - image not used for display purposes; table footnotes
sect4.programlisting:
Measurement types and major research questions of meta-analysis samples<sup><xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t6-fn1">a</xref></sup> Sample study Major research questions OBE measure TCE constructs and measuresb, c FR AS IU EU Agarwal (1994) The probability of choosing the joint venture form is expected to be moderated by the firm-specific characteristics as well as by country-specific characteristics. B CD (I) CR (I) ...

B, binary measure; C, categorical measure; E, equity percentage; F, foreign sales ratio; H, experience in host country; I, composite index; M, multiple measures; N, number of countries; R, ratio; S, surveyed measure; Y, number of years

FR, free-riding potential; AS, asset specificity; IU, internal uncertainty; EU, external uncertainty; measure type in parenthesis

FR is not a parallel construct of AS, but rather a property of AS

sect2.title: Supplementary information
sect2.para: Supplementary items are block-level objects that contain additional information relating to an article and are captured using <supplementary-material>.
Characteristics of supplementary material which should be captured within <floats-group>:

listitem.para: It has a label like "Supplementary Information" or "Supplementary Figures 1℃12".
It may have a title or caption.
It may be referenced by an <xref> with @ref-type="supplementary-material" in the article text.

sect1.title: Sub-articles
sect1.para: <sub-article> is not required for our online academic journals. This section will be expanded upon when we start producing other journals using the JATS DTD.

chapter.title: Elements
chapter.para: These XML elements have specific style rules associated with them. This is not a complete list of XML elements included in the NISO JATS Journal Publishing DTD. For guidance using elements not listed here, consult the JATS Tag Library.

sect1.para: The root element for all articles.
The @article-type attribute is required, e.g. @article-type="le". [This is the equivalent of categ/@id in our old NPG Article DTD, and arttype/@arttype in the AJ DTD.]
attributes:

listitem.para: article-type—(#REQUIRED)
xml:lang—"en" is the default and does not need to be explicitly stated; use "de" for German and "ja" for Japanese (Kanji)
xmlns:mml—Fixed value "http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"
xmlns:oasis—Fixed value "http://docs.oasis-open.org/ns/oasis-exchange/table"
xmlns:xlink—Fixed value "http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"

sect1.para: Used to tag link information to objects outside of the article. The text may be a repeat of the content in the @xlink:href or it may be different.
attributes:

listitem.para: @ext-link-type—set as "uri" for a link to a website (starting with "http:" or "/"); "ftp" for a link to an ftp site [*plus any additional possibilities*] (#REQUIRED)
@xlink:href—Holds an identifier of or locator to an object available through or at that resource. (#REQUIRED)

sect1.para: Contains the ISSN(s) for the journal.
Articles must have at least one <issn>.
If a journal has a print and electronic ISSN, include in successive <issn> tags.
attributes:

listitem.para: pub-type—Set as "ppub" for a print ISSN and "epub" for an electronic ISSN. (#REQUIRED)

sect1.para: See Journal metadata for examples of markup.
This element takes the value of the journal pcode, e.g. "nutd" for Nutrition & Diabetes, "nneuro" for Nature Neuroscience.
attributes:

listitem.para: journal-id-type—Set as "publisher". (#REQUIRED)

sect1.para: See Journal metadata for examples of markup.
The complete title of the journal in which the article is published should be contained in the child <journal-title> element.
Do not use <abbrev-journal-title>, <journal-subtitle> or <trans-title-group>.
See Journal metadata for examples of markup.
The publisher name ("Nature Publishing Group", "Palgrave Macmillan") should be contained in the child <publisher-name> element.
Do not use <publisher-loc>.
See Journal metadata for examples of markup.
Links to related articles [*lots of possible link types - give full explanation when all have been covered*]
attributes:
Used to reference objects within the article. Do not include emphasis or punctuation within the element.
@rid may contain multiple id values.

table.title: Required values for @ref-type [verify against NPG practice - I don't think we assign ids to a lot of these elements]

sect1.para: [*Different to NPG practice*] Tag ranges of cross references by including an <xref> for the first item, an en-dash (–), and an <xref> for the last item.
The changes in education level demonstrate the changing attitudes. 1–3
The changes in education level demonstrate the changing attitudes.1–3
<xref> may be empty or contain text. For example,
sect1.programlisting: In the presented 3D ground-plane cloak, we choose the parameter distribution in the x–z plane as that for the 2D cloak given in ref. 18. Then, we get the full 3D parameter distributions by rotating it around the z axis. Comparing with the original designs, the 2D ground-plane cloak described in reference Ma et al. has a much smaller size (about four times smaller).
sect1.para: attributes:

listitem.para: ref-type—This is the @id of the referenced object. (#REQUIRED)
rid—see the table above for allowed values and ID/IDREF prefixes. (#REQUIRED)
id—Do not use.
